message.1.1: I don't know if this is the right place but I need some advice on how to train a classifier using a data set with multiple feature types: text, integers, floats, dates
message.1.3: My first approach was to convert each feature to binary, example: feature 1 -> \the word w_i is in column j?\ , feature 2 -> \the value in column j is greater than 10?\ feature 3 -> \the month in the date of column j was abril?\ etc.
message.1.4: by the way, Oliver Grisel: Hi! :D
message.1.5: This message is without content. I wonder if anyone hangs out here.
message.1.6: @mac2bua, I just saw your message. It's probably better to ask specific question with running code snippets on toy example data on stackoverflow. You might be interested in having a look at sklearn_pandas for feature extraction from heterogeneously typed columns. FeaturesUnion might also be helpful.
message.1.7:
@ogrisel Thanks a lot for the advice! Fortunately I found this very useful blog: http://bit.ly/1mPEEhH and I decided to start using feature union and pipelines. The result was very good! :smile: 
I know that you are a member of the core team of scikit learn so I'd like to thank you, sklearn is so awesome!. 
Just one more question: Is there any easy way to get the name of the features?  So often I needed to print out the names in order to understand the relationship between them and the different classes. I wrote some code that gather the information of the different vocabularies in the case of the textual or categorical features and the name of the column in the case of the numerical ones. 
Sorry for my bad english!
message.1.8: No, not in general unfortunately: most of the time the data will get internally converted to numpy arrays for efficiency and code simplicity reasons  and even if the column were named in the original representation (e.g. a DataFrame) that information is lost along the way.

message.1.19: what is the issue number of dtype=object?
message.1.22: Most of the bug-fixes are isolated to one estimator. So I think they are important for the release, but shouldn't interact with other issues so much. The ones that are more API-ish are the dtype=object one (https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/4057), the clustering / pipeline one https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/4064 and the input validation one https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/4136
message.1.24: the last two interact somewhat. not sure how clear that is from the PR but the main thing in the input validation is that it extends common tests to estimators that don't inherit from clustering, classification, regression or transformation mixins
message.1.25: I'll try but I'm not sure I'll finish writing the pipeline integration tests today
message.1.26: oh and going toward the release, we need to fix the bugs and regressions in isotonic regression :-/ I don't think a fix exists yet
message.1.29: I saw it broke the calibration PR
message.1.30: too many open tabs, my firefox is so slow at times...
message.1.31: it did? I didn't see that. haha I know the open tabs issue. Well the ``slinear`` broke some cases of ``fit`` and ``fit_transform`` not doing the same thing. Maybe it broke other things, too.
message.1.32: Bugs that are not regressions are that fit and fit_transform were not consistent before in the case of ties, and that having sample_weight=0 in multiple places can lead to infinite loops in the isotonic regression code
message.1.34: I agree. I proposed a fix in one of the issues. Maybe just remove the implementation of ``fit_transform``, that is use the naive fit.transform, and mask out sample_weight=0. That should get rid of the worst bugs.
message.1.35: but doesn't solve all issues with tie-breaking, I think.
message.1.36: some discussion here: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/2507 and in the issues linked at the bottom
message.1.37: So that was a list of the \hard\ issues / PRs. If you want I can also give you a list of the simple bug fixes lol
message.1.38: what are you working on with clusterlib btw?
message.1.39: I want to implement the `concurrent.futures` API. That includes porting cloudpickle.py to Python 3 or implemeting something similar with dill.
message.1.40: The goal is to be able to use SGE / SLURM clusters easily, without having to write bash or boilerplate python scripts.
message.1.41: There is also cloudpi.pe to watch in the same space.
message.1.42: going grab some lunch, see you later
message.1.43: Args. I am slightly confused by the current API requirements in pipeline. If ``fit_transform`` accepts ``y=None`` we don't require ``transform`` to accept a ``y=None``. That is somewhat inconsistent and weird, I think...
message.1.44: Huh ok transform is never passed ``y`` at all... never mind...

message.1.78:
A general suggestion... I feel it would be more helpful to debug test results if we replaced docstrings for tests by comment... 
Output when a docstring is present for a test
```
Tests all estimators which support partial_fit ... ok
Tests all estimators which support partial_fit ... ok
Tests all estimators which support partial_fit ... ok
```
Output when no docstring is present for a test
```
test_common.test_partial_fit('Perceptron', <class 'sklearn.linear_model.perceptron.Perceptron'>) ... ok
test_common.test_partial_fit('Perceptron', <class 'sklearn.linear_model.perceptron.Perceptron'>) ... ok
test_common.test_partial_fit('Perceptron', <class 'sklearn.linear_model.perceptron.Perceptron'>) ... ok
test_common.test_partial_fit('SGDClassifier', <class 'sklearn.linear_model.stochastic_gradient.SGDClassifier'>) ... ok
```

message.1.278: Is there a way to make `GridSearchCV` act without the CV part ( do parameters `cv=None` or `refit` help in this context )?
message.1.279:
You can precompute a single test train split:
train_idx, validation_idx = train_test_split(n_samples, test_size=0.2, random_state=0)
cv = [(train_idx, validation_idx)]
GridSearchCV(model, cv=cv).fit(X, y)

message.1.341:
I started thinking about it, we can do:
- general intro to ML in Python with scikit-learn
- couple of words on the project organization and the team of contributors
- highlight of some new stuff in 0.16: improvement on speed or scalability of some methods such as:
   - IncrementalPCA
   - clustering (I am preparing a notebook comparing DBSCAN, MiniBatchKMeans, KMeans and Birch on 100k blobish 2D points to simulate someone working to extract Point of Interests from raw geo location data (e.g. GSM phone records)
- new Approximate Nearest Neighbors search with LSHForest
Then for the future we could talk about TSNE and algorithmic improvements under review in the pipeline

message.1.358: what's on todays agenda for the release?
message.1.360: no progress on isotonic I see
message.1.361: would you mind having a look at https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/issues/4324
message.1.362: I guess I start reviewing the non-release PRs now. Or is there anything to review left?
message.1.363: Delaying the beta even more seems a bit silly to me, but the only other option is to merge the remaining urgent fixes with fewer reviews
message.1.364: I am having a look at the DBSCAN. Let's release the beta tomorrow. Whatever the review state of the remaining PRs. we will do backports for the fixes afterwards for the second beta.
message.1.365: you want a second beta? Alright....
message.1.367: it depends how stable we find the beta
message.1.368: I would like to merge this https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/4028 before cutting the beta branch
message.1.369: go for it. It shouldn't interfere with anything.
message.1.371: Do you think we should get this one in soon: https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/4228
message.1.372: If it's ready soon, � for a backport to the 0.16.X branch.
message.1.374: maybe we can do: beta tomorrow, continue backports of fixes and target 0.16 in 2 or 3 weeks. And if we fix additional important bugs, 0.16.1 in a month and half
message.1.376: we should really release more regularly.
message.1.377: I will be in PyCon at that point but you can do the 0.16.1 with the help of others if I am not responsive enough at that point.
message.1.378: Alright. I don't think I'll make it this year.
message.1.379: you are not coming to scipy are you?
message.1.381: I was planning to attend ICML as a free-styler because is just 1h by train
message.1.383: Hey :) could you help me with #4228 ? I don't understand a few things... When testing you said I could use multilabel data right? but which classifier do I test against? (or if you might have time could you take over?)
message.1.384: Try a tree? Or use OneVsRestClassifer(LogisticRegression).
message.1.386: will grid search propagate the parameters from `OneVsRestClassifier` to `LogisticRegression`?
message.1.388: probably with ``estimator__``. But I'd rather go with a tree, which should work
message.1.389: okay I'll push in sometime... pl see if I am in the right direction or kindly take over... sorry for having kept you waiting over that :)
message.1.390: A small doubt do you use multiple monitors? ;)
message.1.392: Just curious how @amueller could be online and commenting at the same time :O\nI am online sometimes while I work since I use vim in a transparent guake terminal over the gitter chat window... :)
message.1.393: no transparency here. I technically have a laptop monitor and a large one, but in the office I currently only use the large one. Still context-switching too much.
message.1.394: I have the gitter tab just always open
message.1.396: are you working on https://github.com/scikit-learn/scikit-learn/pull/4228 now or should I go for it? I only have like 2 hours of work left today, though ;)
message.1.397: Please go for it :) :P Most ests don't seem to support sparse y... :)
message.1.398:
```
======================================================================
ERROR: sklearn.tree.tests.test_tree.test_sparse_input('DecisionTreeClassifier', 'sparse-mix', None)
----------------------------------------------------------------------
Traceback (most recent call last):
  File /usr/local/lib/python2.7/dist-packages/nose/case.py\ line 197, in runTest
    self.test(*self.arg)
  File \.../scikit-learn/sklearn/tree/tests/test_tree.py\ line 1051, in check_sparse_input
    y_sparse)
  File \.../scikit-learn/sklearn/tree/tree.py\ line 221, in fit
    
umber of samples=%d\ % (len(y), n_samples))
ValueError: Number of labels=1 does not match number of samples=20
-------------------- >> begin captured stdout << ---------------------
```
Perhaps the `len(y)` needs to be changed to `_num_samples(y)` here...
